  • Wellington Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences
  • Communications and marketing

Communications and marketing

The WFHSS Communications and Marketing team is your first port of call for publications, social media, media, internal comms, events, marketing, and websites.

For all communications and marketing enquiries:

  • Jo Fisher, Communications and Marketing Manager
  • Natalie Hampshire, Senior Communications and Marketing Adviser
  • Sam Potts, Communications and Marketing Adviser

WFHSS weekly bulletin

This internal e-newsletter is sent out every Monday. If you want your events, new books, media coverage, calls for papers, or other information included, send details to Sam Potts by 5 pm the Thursday prior.

Media engagement guide

Our media engagement guide provides advice on working with the media to reach bigger and different audiences with your research and expertise, including which media to engage with, ways to engage, how to prepare for a media interview, and how social media fits in the mix.

Media directory—Find a researcher

Contact details for a number of academic staff are included in the Find a researcher directory which can be accessed by journalists through the University website. You can add yourself to the directory if you are happy to be contacted for expert comment in your area of research expertise.

Digital screens

Digital screens on the overbridge, levels 1 and 3 of Murphy and the Hugh McKenzie foyer are used to promote WFHSS and FoE activities and events. Contact Sam Potts if you would like a DID to be created or for more information.

Communications and marketing resources

A wide range of communications and marketing resources, including brand guidelines, branded templates (including for letters, memos, PowerPoint, student notes covers), advice on planning and running events, and social media guidelines are available on the Communications and Marketing group intranet pages.

Before you apply

Some research activities require human ethics approval before they proceed, in order to protect participants, researchers and communities.

Health and disability research

If you are undertaking health or disability research, you'll need to make sure you are submitting to the right committee.

The application process

Once you've prepared your application, it will proceed through the Human Ethics Committee approval process.

Preparing your application

There's lots of help available to assist you when you're preparing your application.

After you have approval

After you've been granted approval, you should stay in touch and let us know if anything changes with your project.

Human Ethics Committee

The University’s Human Ethics Committee and subcommittees are responsible for the assessment of human ethics applications.

Using the online application system (ResearchMaster)

Applications for ethics should be made online through ResearchMaster. Try logging into ResearchMaster using your usual University username and password as most staff and students have access automatically. If you do not have access to ResearchMaster, download the Access to Ethics Online Applications form (Word), complete the details and email it to ethicsadmin@vuw.ac.nz.

ResearchMaster can be accessed from any computer, including offsite. Refer to Using the Online Ethics Form: Guide for Applicants (PDF) if you require assistance to complete your application online. Note that the system does time out after a certain period so it is a good idea to save regularly or risk losing your work.

Notifications

You should receive an email notification once you have submitted your application. If you don’t receive this email, this is probably because the system has the wrong address recorded for you. It can hold up your application significantly if you don’t receive system notifications. The ResearchMaster system uses the address you have in Student Records—please log into Student Records to check it is correct.

To find out more

If you have any questions about the awards, contact:
